title: 111_hr1957
content: The Act is titled the "Helping Families Afford Tuition Act" and amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a Higher Education Tuition Credit. The "Helping Families Afford Tuition Act" introduces a Higher Education Tuition Credit allowing a 50% tax credit on qualified tuition expenses up to $10,000 for eligible students. There are limitations based on modified adjusted gross income to reduce the credit amount. The "Helping Families Afford Tuition Act" introduces a Higher Education Tuition Credit with limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income exceeding certain thresholds. The Higher Education Tuition Credit is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's gross income for the taxable year, excluding amounts under specific sections. The credit is only allowed for a maximum of 5 taxable years and requires the individual to be at least a half-time student for part of the year to qualify for the credit. The Higher Education Tuition Credit is limited to eligible students for up to 5 years of post-secondary education. The credit is denied if the student has completed 5 years of education or has a felony drug offense. The Higher Education Tuition Credit is limited to eligible students for up to 5 years of post-secondary education, but the credit is denied if the student has a felony drug offense. Eligible students must meet specific requirements and carry at least half of the normal full-time workload for their course of study. The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' refers to tuition and fees required for enrollment at an eligible educational institution for courses of instruction. It does not include expenses related to education involving sports. The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' excludes costs for sports, games, or hobbies unless part of the degree program. It also excludes nonacademic fees like student activity fees and insurance expenses. An eligible educational institution is defined as one described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible to participate in a program. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses under the Higher Education Act of 1965 requires taxpayers to include the individual's name and taxpayer identification number on their tax return. Any scholarships or payments for the benefit of the individual must be subtracted from the total expenses for the academic period. The tax credit allows for the exclusion of qualified scholarships, educational assistance allowances, and payments for educational expenses from gross income for eligible individuals. Treatment of expenses paid by a dependent for qualified tuition and related expenses during their taxable year may be credited to another taxpayer if a deduction is allowed for that individual by the other taxpayer. Additionally, prepayments for academic periods starting within the first 3 months following the taxable year are also considered for tax purposes. For tax purposes, prepayments for academic periods starting within the first 3 months following the taxable year are considered. No double benefit is allowed, and married individuals must file joint returns to claim the credit. Nonresident aliens must be treated as resident aliens for the credit to apply. The IRS allows a credit for qualified tuition and related expenses, but it is repealed in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary can create regulations for recapturing the credit if refunded in a later taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking certain sections and making conforming amendments to various other sections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking certain sections and making conforming amendments to various other sections, including changes to section 25A in subsections (c)(3)(B)(v), (e)(3)(B), (d)(2)(C)(i), and (d)(4)(B), as well as adding a flush sentence to section 1400O. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking certain sections and making conforming amendments to various other sections. This includes changes to section 25A in subsections (c)(3)(B)(v), (e)(3)(B), (d)(2)(C)(i), and (d)(4)(B), as well as adding a flush sentence to section 1400O. Additionally, references to section 25A are updated in subsections (e) of section 6050S, subparagraph (J) of section 6213(g)(2), and the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section regarding higher education tuition credit will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010.
